item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description: This is some test text of the blogdown knit function to git # here's a simple plot. x <- c(1,2,3,4,5) y <- c(2,4,8,16,32) plot(x,y) Including Plots You can also embed plots. See Figure 1 for example: par(mar = c(0, 1, 0, 1)) pie( c(280, 60, 20), c('Sky', 'Sunny side of pyramid', 'Shady side of pyramid'), col = c('#0292D8', '#F7EA39', '#C4B632'), init.angle = -50, border = NA ) Figure 1: A fancy pie chart.

item.title: Sublime Text test link
item.description: test link to a text post Testing the functionality of writing a text post in Sublime Text as a .md document and loading into the content folder within the git repository.

item.title: Sublime Text test link
item.description: test link to a text post Testing the functionality of writing a text post in Sublime Text as a .md document and loading into the content folder within the git repository.

item.title: A Plain Markdown Post
item.description: This is a post written in plain Markdown (*.md) instead of R Markdown (*.Rmd). The major differences are: You cannot run any R code in a plain Markdown document, whereas in an R Markdown document, you can embed R code chunks (```{r}); A plain Markdown post is rendered through Blackfriday, and an R Markdown document is compiled by rmarkdown and Pandoc. There are many differences in syntax between Blackfriday’s Markdown and Pandoc’s Markdown.

item.title: About
item.description: This is a “hello world” example website for the blogdown package. The theme was forked from @jrutheiser/hugo-lithium-theme and modified by Yihui Xie.

item.title: test_post
item.description: test header test prose x <- c(1,2,3,4,5) y <- c(2,4,8,16,32) plot(x,y)

item.title: testpage
item.description: here is my CV R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com. When you click the Knit button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:
